What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the history of sedition and dissent and how it has been expressed through language. I also learned some about how to analyze texts alongside each other in order to parallel them and gain insights into both.
In this course, we developed a critical eye in the analysis of papers relating to the support and criticisms of Free Speech.

There was a lot of writing done in the course. I learned how to write a full length paper and write papers critiquing a piece through the lens of another piece, write research papers, form arguments. Basic writing class
How to properly dissect a paper and critically analyze it. How to properly write well-formed essays.
Discussion and study of sedition and dissent from a primarily philosophical perspective. Case studies from recent years and connections to philosophers, theory, and historical studies.
developed a new perspective on what exactly is free speech, and formed new opinions on the regulation of free expression

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Our presentations at the end followed by Q/A were nice to facilitate discussion about the material we'd been covering all semester
Weaknesses: I didn't learn as much as I wanted about actually improving my own writing which is why I took the course - it felt more like a history of sedition and dissent than an English class and we didn't receive enough feedback on our own writing. The readings were also excessively long at times and could've definitely been cut to just include the most important parts that we actually ended up discussing in class.

Professor Ranks is a very very good professor and is very good at instructing while at the same time guiding discussions, but I think some times the discussions were cut a little short. Also, she has not given back grades for many of my assignments, so the term si essentially over and I still do not really know how I am doing in the course, which is a little frustrating.
I wish the instructor can give our grades back. Even till the very end of the course, we haven't received a grade on a single assignment. The course itself is super engaging though.

I really liked the content of this course! Prof. Ranks is incredibly knowledgeable and helped us unpack complex topics in class (I still don't understand Milton though). Our discussions were always productive, and we gained new insight on examples that most of us knew about from the news.
I think it would have been nice to receive more feedback on the final drafts (see below) and to use more real-world examples.
the topic and class discussions are very interesting, but the lack of feedback or grades on final drafts of essays is a downside

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Nothing to be improved in regards to this
The breakout room small group discussions were fine
This class was very consistently well-suited to the online format; we used discussion posts to interact with each other and talked about the (easily accessible) readings during lecture.
the small class meetings worked very well, especially the class discussions and peer presentations

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No, or at least not if you're taking it in order to become a better writer, specifically for essays. I did not receive the amount of feedback that I anticipated nor did I receive it in the time-frame that Yale usually holds English professors to. It was relatively interesting to learn about the history of sedition and dissent which is pertinent to today, but overall not worth the time/work for what I got out of it.
I would highly recommend this course.
Yes, it is an interesting class and good to fulfill WR credit. I appreciated the discussions we had and though they were good.
Yes, absolutely!
Yes for the content. See below about Prof. Ranks' grading.
yes, since the topic is very interesting, but you should be prepared to not receive any grades

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Just virtual discussion
none
